job_title: Senior Marketing Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Great work life balance Awesome colleagues 10% 403b match 100% free healthcare for employees w/ option to add family for a small cost Great PTO Really healthy work environment 35 hour work week Permanent WFH CEO is the sweetest man ever. A washed up jazz musician turned heart doctor turned CEO. Also lead the Smithsonian Institute. Just an awesome human being. They've bee really dedicated to their employees during the pandemic. Prefers everyone to call him David rather than Dr. Skorton.
cons: The salary might be less than a more profit driven company? Not sure. The benefits and amazing WL balance is worth it Not a ton of room to grow at the company forever if you start in a lower ranked job. Only so much space on a team.

job_title: Contact Center Representative in Washington, DC
pros: Great staff, not bad management
cons: Barely any room for growth on the help desk

review_title: Getting paid, learning skills and actually making a difference
pros:
The AAMC offers what you might expect from a substantial employer -- competitive salary & the chance to grow your professional skills. The part that's different is that we're generally rooting for each other. I typically don't have to watch my back because my colleagues are generally trying to help me be successful. I have built genuine friendships with my colleagues. When there's a problem, we generally get together and figure out how to solve it rather than focusing on who to blame. 

Having family with serious illness, I understand the importance/significance of teaching hospitals and producing exceptional doctors. Feeling like my job and my organization are helping to improve society and real people's lives is a pretty great feeling. If you haven't, try it sometime. :)
cons:
A number of nonprofit stereotypes apply here -- we tend to make decisions slowly and by consensus. If you're used to an aggressive, action oriented work culture, there will likely be some frustration at the pace of things.

People tend to camp out in management positions (hard to give up the work life balance and amazing 10% 401k contribution) so there's not as many opportunities for promotion.

review_title: Great Benefits and Work life Balance
pros: Great benefits and work life balance. Dedicated President and CEO however cluster chiefs are not on the same page as the CEO.
cons: Your success is dependent on your supervisor. The pay is decent however HR/work unit does not adjust pay structure due to inflation changes.

pros: The AAMC really puts stock in it it's employees.
cons: Not many I can think of.

pros: Organized systems; employees tend to stay a long time so a lot of historical knowledge is retained; remote work
cons: I cannot think of any cons.

pros: Environment is good and work from home balance is great
cons: No growth if you not a favorite

job_title: Client Technical Support Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Remote Work, Flexible, Diversity, Great Wages
cons: I don't have any cons

pros: Work life balance is great
cons: Maybe some people don’t like being remote, I did.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Washington, DC
pros: Good place to work. Nice working environment with legacy tech stack.
cons: No growth. All the work was outsourced.

review_title: If You Don't Expect or Crave Change and Improvement, You'll Be Fine
pros:
Great people to work with 
Great benefits
Great networking opportunities
cons:
They still operate like it's 1950. Departments have no idea what other departments are doing. Projects take forever to complete with no KPI or other ways to measure effectiveness or success. 

There's usually no where to move upwards or laterally. So the position you take, is the one you've got...forever. 

If you go in thinking you'll change anything or update how they work, you will get your heart broken over and over and over again. Best way to survive is to sink into the routine and don't make waves.

pros: Nice people and a great culture
cons: Little professional development. No room for advancement as no one wants to leave.

job_title: Learning Operations Manager in Washington, DC
pros: Collaborating with colleagues and having a variety of challenging projects. Some departments were far better to work in than others.
cons: Many politics to navigate and professional development opportunities were limited.

Decent pay with great benefits.

review_title: Supportive environment and wonderful place to work

job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Washington, DC

pros: Good benefits and flexible hours

pros: Great benefits, lots of smart colleagues, many opportunities to get involved.
cons: Culture and experience can vary widely between units and departments.

pros:
Coworkers are smart, passionate people who have big dreams and ambitions for medical education. Benefits are great and overall management tries to take care of employees and provide a great working environment. There are tons of opportunities for learning and professional development within the organization and my experience is that management encourages employees to use break time to take advantage of this. 

Work life balance was great - while things get busy and sometimes work is just crazy, my managers really supported me during those times and tried to make sure that they did what they needed to so that I could get things done and go home. 

It's a friendly culture with great people. I made friends while working there and would recommend it to anyone considering it as an opportunity.

I would 100% go back to work there, if life opportunities brought me back in that direction.
cons:
Some departments are better than others for opportunities and professional development.  It is a large organization and opportunities will depend a lot on the particular cluster or manager. 

Despite efforts to be more collaborative and work better across the organization, finding information and processes outside of ones cluster can at times be difficult. 

The organization seems to be struggling with a balance between being nimble and responsive to opportunity and remaining stable and focused with mission. Recent changes seem to be trending toward the more bureaucracy and review, however it remains to be seen how the organization can stay balanced.

pros: great place to be and dynamic organization
cons: none that I can think of

pros:
A lot of opportunities
Great benefits.
Missions oriented Organization
Decent Health Insurance
Commuter Benefits
cons: Experience dependent on your direct line manager

review_title: The Passion and Motivation is Over!
pros: Work hours; benefits; location; fellow colleagues who are talented and passionate about the non-profit environment and the mission; those managers that fight for their staff even if they risk their reputation among peers.
cons: Promotion/pay is stagnant and favors those who either 'network' or are the true 'poster children' of the organization. Many managers have no idea what the middle level employees are truly doing to make the trains run on time or even how their program should be managed efficiently. Also, there is too many layers just to get constituents' answers and provide excellent customer service. Lastly, low morale is now the daily mood within many departments but no one is willing to address the tough issues honestly and fairly across the organization.

pros:
Work life balance
Benefits
Coworkers are friendly
Company has fantastic values
cons:
Not a lot of upward mobility
Low salary

pros: A great flexible place to work.
cons: Hard to grow fast in this company.

review_title: Cushy job with little to no room for growth. Not for the ambitious or minorities
pros: Great benefits, work-life balance, continued education stipend, beautiful office space, great mission, genuine efforts for employee engagement, mission
cons: Minimal salary increases  2-3% max annually. Evaluations are linked to salary increases but they are elusive about the formula/process and there is a lack of transparency. Lack of diversity in senior leadership. Little to no room for growth, or promotion-especially for people of color. Promotion opportunities provided for the same people as evidenced by lack of diversity in leadership. Mid-level management is not evaluated based on staff development and outcomes rather their individual contributions  which leads to micromanaging. Obvious cliques and "inside crowd" that keeps resources and opportunities for their friends and favorites.   Most people of color , albeit educated with advanced degrees occupy most of the roles that  are low-level or entry level or (admin related & call center). They take roles that allow them a "foot in the door" only to find out that growth within the company is rare unless you leave and come back or move departments.

job_title: Community Health Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Great Benefits, Work-Life Balance is Superior
cons: Seem hard to make changes

review_title: AAMC - Place to retire your career!
pros:
- Good benefits
- Very laid back work place
- Non profit employer
cons:
A typical very badly managed organization.

- A lot of work is outsourced to India
- Too many middle managers like three managers to one employee
- Management does whole lot of nothing
- Very bureaucratic management
- Business culture at its worst
- Innovation does not exist
- Work equipment is 10+ years old
- Unfriendly staff - people don't talk unless they have business purpose
- Too many executives doing nothing

Ideal job for someone who just wants a job and not looking for career growth. AAMC hires a lot of contractors and consulting companies. It is the norm to get yelled at if you are a contractor or third party consulting company at AAMC. People can hear the yelling across the hall ways. Human resource is all eyes and ears closed about this kind of stuff at AAMC. Think twice if you are leaving for a consulting opportunity here. 
A lot of senior managers make decisions at AAMC and typically you never interact with them and they don't know what you do there or your skills. My 2 cents.. this is not the ideal place for someone looking to build a career. It's probably a good place for a senior executive looking to retire soon. AAMC executives essentially have no accountability or drive - guess it's the expectation for a non-profit organization.

PS: This is my honest experience - not sure why others say AAMC is great place to work. Perhaps they did not have better experience elsewhere?

pros: Excellent benefits. great location in DC.
cons:
Everyone here is super smart but they over compensate. The cultural is focused on who can make the best strategy and use the biggest words...without actually accomplishing anything. Everyday I was super stressed about being right as opposed to being innovative or creative.

Directors seemed to focus too much time on "managing" an employee versus lifting and mentoring them up. I'm glad to be away from this culture and that silly open space that felt like I was in Kindergarten being monitored by my supervisor.

pros: The organization has a lot of smart and passionate individuals who are excited about making an impact in medical education.
cons:
It's an incredibly political top-down environment where poorly informed leadership drives decisions that stifle creativity and productivity. There exists a system of favortism which enables unqualified employees to rise within the organization while, at the same time, discourages and suppresses those who have and can show value. The organization is saying that it is looking to transform but the actions of leaders within organization portrays the exact opposite. I am utterly dismayed with AAMC and cannot see progress with the way things stand now. 

As long you are friendly with someone in authority you can get away with anything.

I will not advise or refer someone to join AAMC. All this talk of career growth and development is pointless since neither the culture nor environment exists to suppprt that.

pros: The AAMC has a great mission and that is focused on improving healthcare for all by ensuring quality education for future and current physicians and medical researchers. They promote from within and are keen to offer educational opportunities for current employees. They frequently seek input from employees about their experiences and are actively working to improve the company culture.
cons: Unfortunately, for many of the reasons that working for the AAMC might be considered a check in the "Pros" column, it can be very challenging to work there, especially if you are an outsider coming into the organization.  Although upper level management is actively working to improve the culture, it isn't quite filtering down to the line managers yet.  Trust issues, inconsistencies with applying company policies, expectations and opportunities for success and continued improvement can be a real challenge.  Intelligence in the form of "book smarts" is prized above real leadership qualities which leads to ineffective and even harmful managers being promoted quickly and issues of high turnover and employee burnout abound.

review_title: Overall a generally good company to work for
job_title: ERAS Client and Technical Analyst II in Washington, DC
pros: The leadership team overall tries to make the AAMC an excellent company that focuses on its employees.  Received great training opportunities and they paid the majority of my tuition for me to go to school at University of Maryland University College. Every summer we had the opportunity to take courses at Learning Tree. I appreciated the travel opportunities as I was able to visit many states that I may not have visited on my own.
cons: IMHO I was laid off (along with several others) to be replaced with people who would perform the same job for less money.  A lot us that came in during the "boom" years our salaries were excellent however when the economy turned they could not justify a significant pay decrease so a bunch of us were laid off.

review_title: Used to be a good company, not any more.
job_title: Senior Research Analyst in Washington, DC
pros: Benefits are good and most colleagues smart and nice. Used to a smaller friendly company where everyone knows each other and help each other. Old CEO was much more for public goods than for making most profit. Has a solid income flow from medical student application fees.
cons: The environment has been toxic since the current CEO came which is all about making money out of your constituents whom you used to provide service for. Meeting fees skyrocketed that many schools find hard to afford. A lot of fluff and pile on layers of managers on top of staff who actually do the job. Since moving to the new building have seen a lot of long time mid level employees leaving or retiring early, or even worse more than half a dozen died suddenly in less than a year of moving to new site. Bad fengshui.

review_title: Great Benefits, but don't expect to grow there.
pros: Awesome benefits - health care,  emergency child care options (off site), wellness activities are free (weight watchers, quit smoking, yoga, meditation, etc). This organization has a ton of money and you would do well here if you want stability, retirement, et cetera.
cons: I personally witnessed a number of non-qualified people get promoted or hired because of who they knew at the association, and there were great candidates that had been  (and are probably STILL doing) the work that should have been promoted. There is a college Fraternity/sorority "cool kids" mentality in a lot of the departments. Teleworking is an option for SOME, depending on how much your boss likes you.

review_title: ok place to work, laid back
pros: vacation, 403b matching, sick days, health insurance if you are single or you spouse has his/her own. location in DC near metro/Georgetown, near Trader Joe's, work is ok, its a very laid back place to work. alot of folks come here and indicated that it's not stressful as in their past jobs, generous training in IT
cons: very bureaucratic,  no room for advancement unless there is a job posting, The continuum for pay raises changes each year depending on the market, this way they pay folks less Very small raises increases, sometimes  no Easter Holiday, only 1 day for X-mas (even though quite a few people indicated that it would be nice to have a few more days off during the X-mas holiday, its very quiet at work during this time ) People tend to point the finger alot when things go wrong and blame other departments

review_title: AAMC is a great place to work
pros: The people and the work.  The work is very rewarding, it great to know we all do something to help medical education be better.  The people are great, we have some staff who have been at the association more than 30 years.  In this day and age, that's amazing. It is so nice to come to a job that you enjoy.  You are at work for long hours, and to enjoy it is great.  Staff are offered chances for training, inside and outside of the office.  This training helps staff do their jobs better, and serve our constiuents better.  You can always find staff that are willing to help each other.
cons: We are in two buildings.  Being in one building would be nice.  We spend a lot of time walking between the buildings for meetings.    Having staff in the same building will help streamline a lot of processes.

review_title: IT Salaries are generous, work culture is OK.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Washington, DC
pros: IT Salaries (especially programmer, BA , BI ) are  good at AAMC.  Work-load is manageable.  You will find good people. Diversity is good  here. They've had some turnover recently due to a new office building that increases commutes for some Virginia employees. If you enjoy PMP-style management, practices and operations (ie. the inverse of a startup) - this place is for you !
cons: Most  managers are incompetent.    IT of course needs to make life miserable for engineers with PMP  'best practices'.  Of late, with multiple re-orgs of teams, the've created a 'rockstar' culture - the good thing about that is it rocks the boat, the bad thing is people either are left out, or get burnt-out running in the same place.

pros: As a non-profit, the AAMC generally operates on a 35 hour work week so it's easy to achieve a work-life balance. There will be a few hectic times of year with long hours usually leading up to or during big meetings or events. People are generally friendly and easy to work with, and there are many passionate employees that want to positively impact academic medicine and healthcare.
cons: The association can be rather silo'd and you may not get much exposure to parts of the company you're interested in unless you really hunt them down. There are a lot of long-term employees (10-20 years), especially manager roles, that are great for institutional memory, but not always great for innovation and exploring new ways of doing things. Younger employees tend to stay only 2-3 years as there aren't that many opportunities for growth or advancement in many departments.

review_title: Great place to start your career and build connections.
pros: The association is truly mission driven and dedicated to improving graduate medical education and beyond. The employees are great and it is truly a great place to work.
cons: The association is probably growing to big too fast and often finds itself trying to be a major player in DC while remaining a bit unfocused/overreaching. It often forgets it's a nonprofit and tries to run things more like a private business enterprise.

pros: The people are awesome - intelligent, passionate and committed. The atmosphere around the office is great. The work is meaningful. The company culture is awesome and the benefits are generous. Management is very committed to happy employees and their development.
cons: They definitely have a certain idea of the best career path - including multiple degrees and the right internships and job history. If you don't fit it, you will be taken less seriously. HR is opaque; seriously, no one knows what goes on in there or with your salary. The office culture is collaborative and growing more so with an open office plan, which may be a pro or a con, depending on your likes.

review_title: Great benefits, but that's about it.
pros:
-It is a job, and the salary was decent.

-Top-notch benefits package (no employee contributions for health care and dental plans, the plans themselves are very good with low deductibles--minimal out-of-pocket expenses, AAMC will match your retirement contributions immediately upon hire if you come from another non-profit organization,  SmartBenefits for metro/bus). If it wasn't for the benefits package my review would probably only be one star.

-High value on work/life balance. Employees are encouraged to take time off. Also, PTO does not need to be used if you come in late or leave early.

-Metro accessible
cons:
There are many. Here are the key ones.

-Not a relaxing work environment. Everyday I felt stressed out when I didn't need to be. 

-Many of my assigned tasks/responsibilities seemed counterproductive towards my career development, and were not in line with my expectations of the position based on the interview process.

-Managers fuss constantly over mundane details such as wording or font used in emails.

-Minor decisions such as re-arranging text on a survey site are constantly over-analyzed and require hours of meetings and discussion.

-Management preaches collaboration, however, I was unable to reach out directly to other departments at the AAMC without drawing the ire of my supervisor because I did not coordinate the outreach through them.

-There is no trust in other departments. I have sat in meetings where individuals openly berated other departments in front of my team. I shouldn't be performing tasks for other departments because my supervisor doesn't trust them to do a good job.

-Little opportunity for career development. It was easy to get moved around on to different projects, but none of them differed from each other greatly enough that I was learning anything useful.

-Working here is probably best suited for someone content with doing the same kind of work day in, day out with little variation, and are not interested in furthering their career.

review_title: Good intentions, good people, growing pains
job_title: Lead Software Engineer in Washington, DC
pros: A true mission to improve medical education. Supports a broad and diverse approach (too broad?) Intelligent and motivated staff.
cons: Generous funding and overly broad mission has lead to some uncontrolled growth and spending one wouldn't see at a for-profit organization. Not waste, per se, but too many feet in too many pools. Staff experience can vary wildly based on which "island" one lands on.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Washington, DC
pros: Work-life balance is pretty good. Lots of vacation. Good benefits. Good, smart people. Very diverse organization. Women and minorities in positions of leadership. Public transportation to work in a nice city. This is a good organization with a good mission. You make the world better by working here.
cons: Pay kind of sucks to be honest. A few of the project managers are pretty terrible, though senior managers are generally good.

pros: Good work-life balance, caring colleagues, emphasis on giving back.
cons: IT business units too isolated from each other.  Contract-to-hire process has serious gaps.  Needs to be more transparent.  Internal resumes from present contractors seeking conversion to AAMC employment can get swallowed in online application system.  Many applications not acknowledged.  Hiring managers did not follow up with unsuccessful applicants, even those who had previously been contractors, to notify them of final hiring decisions.   AAMC may be missing many qualified applicants as well as turning off those who did apply but never heard back after several rounds of interviews.

pros:
Exceptional, hard-working colleagues
Critically important work
Excellent benefits
Values employees
cons:
Work/life balance can be challenging
Much like health care, work can end up in silos

pros: Working with various departments and member organizations, I got a better understanding of our mission on various levels. I also felt very appreciated by team members. AAMC had an excellent benefit package and onsite perks.
cons: Too many managers who do nothing to support their staff. If you are not a director, your role is not very important, and neither are you, Way too clickish that starts at the top. Poor leadership and "no open door policies". All rules does not apply to everyone.

review_title: Train Your Managers to be Leaders!
job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Washington, DC
pros: Benefits are very very competitive
cons: the support you receive is dictated by your boss.  if you get the right boss your experience will be awesome. Otherwise, no bueno!

pros: Great benefits...at a price.  The compensation is mainly in the benefits.  Remember you can survive on benefits alone.
cons: Not a good place to be everyday. Culture is awful.

job_title: Director of Applications in Washington, DC
pros:
Great, smart, passionate people.  Important mission.  

Benefits are above average.  

Beautiful facility.
cons:
Corporate culture could use an overhaul.  Too much stagnation and undue influence among long-timers.  

Lip service paid to innovation.  

Senior management plays favorites.

pros:
1. Great people
2. Great Work environment
3. Great work life balance
4. Nice technologies to work on
5. Very good management who really cares about you.
6. You can really prove your worth and you will be recognized.
7. Nice location of the company
8. People are very friendly and welcoming
cons:
1. Management should do a little more investigation into the peoples capabilities and skills.
2. Pay should be a little better based on the skill set and experience.

pros: Great, wonderful place to work.  Incredibly collegial.  Management team dedicated to work-life balance.
cons: This is a great organization that strives to help its members (institutions) and those who interact with the organization throughout their medical career journey (learners).

review_title: Wonderful organization but experience varies by team
pros: Benefits (healthcare, 403b matching, dental, gym perks, commuter stipend), salary, work/life balance
cons: Units operate in silos, some leaders are excellent, others are terrible. The experience working there, like most places, was dictated by your manager. Some teams are truly dysfunctional. I'm also unsure how the organization will hold up in the quickly evolving world of tech.

review_title: Great benefits, relaxed environment, not a lot of upward growth.
pros: Excellent benefits, fairly relaxed environment, forward thinking, and great location downtown.
cons: Below industry standard pay, confused goals and slightly out of touch with their own business model, almost like the government in terms of how long it takes to get anything done, breeds lazy people who barely do their job at the expense of others.

review_title: Excellent opportunity for a summer internship
pros: Working at the AAMC was a great opportunity to experience the political happenings of Washington, DC while still contributing to my interest in health care. The general feeling of the office was one of friendliness and hard work.
cons: Because the office is in DC, dress code and general manner of behavior were more formal than many internships but also allowed for opportunities to meet with important, influential individuals.

review_title: Good projects and the people management system should be enhanced.
pros: most pf the works here are very importanct and have strong influence on the medical education industry,
cons: the performance rating system is a mess. No matter how hard you work, there are only 1 or 2 people in your department can be rewarded as the rating system does not work very well.

job_title: Physical Therapist Assistant in Annapolis, MD
pros: Staff is professional and values learning and development of staff.
cons: The particular job i held had no room for advancement or promotion even through additional schooling.  I know other states approach the position in a diffenrent context.  Extra credentials don't yield extra income.  I attribute most of it to administrative red tape surrounding insurance payouts.

job_title: Technical Support Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Really great group of people, low stress, let you do your work without micromanaging.
cons: Low Pay. Words to get to the 20 word minimum. Didn't seem like much room for advancement.

review_title: Reconsider or at least negotiate higher pay
pros: If you are full time you will have a wide variety of things to choose for from your benefits package, you will also have flexibility in your schedule after the first 6 months to change your schedule or work from home as needed. Also most of this company is small focused teams, within larger departments. You work closely with the same group of people every day in an open workspace and management/HR gets it right when balancing skills, talents and temperaments within these small teams.
cons:
Do you like being promoted? Let that go. You won't be off of your skills, certifications, degrees, experiences or tenure at the job. Promotions are almost non-existent. Title changes are nonexistent.

Do you like creating solutions? Let that go,  company is about maintaining/maintenance of their mission not actually improving it or building their legacy with something new. New ideas are not welcome and will not be approved. 

Do you like endless, meaningless, pointless meetings that eat up the limited time in your day to actually accomplish your work tasks during working hours? You're in the right place!

Do you have a rich appreciation for being micromanaged? 

Do you look forward to performance reviews that will NOT result in assured annual raises, regardless of how much you have increased your workload in special projects, initiatives or absorbing others opportunities after they have left from the stress?

Do you want your pay to be correlative to your work responsibilities? If this doesn't matter to you and you are okay being approached to negotiate your work life balance for understaffed teams where people have quit 4-5 months after being hired - then yes, you should join this place as an employee.

Do you care about

review_title: Pleasant work environment, meaningful and challenging work
pros:
The work is fulfilling, relevant, interesting, and challenging.
The people are nice, communicative, encouraging, fair, and responsible.
The office itself is quiet, clean, and spacious. You get a lot of privacy and amenities (private office, large windows, free coffee/tea, filtered water, covered parking spot for bicycles).
cons: No option to get an elevated desk for standing (without a medical condition). That is my only complaint!

review_title: Watch our for the landmines and watch your back around the sociopaths that you work for!
job_title: IT Program Manager in Washington, DC
pros:
Some of the people were emotionally available for acquaintance like friendships.
Good location on the West End, right next to Rock Creek Park
Reasonable facilities
Comparable benefits package
Some organization sponsored activities
cons:
A majority of the people are emotionally unavailable, unprofessional and unaccountable for their inappropriate actions.
Senior Management is decisive in making up their minds but providing consistent guidance is rare and decisions were often countered by 180 degree changes.
Senior management is consistently inconsistent in supporting their decisions.  A decision at AAMC is like a gazelle roaming freely across the Serengeti.  Whereas, following senior management’s direction without caution within the political environment at AAMC can feel like being pounced by a pride of lions after freely carrying out the direction of senior management, without caution.  If you look closely, you will see the trail of bones in the grass.  Don’t be fooled, if you work at AAMC, those will be your bones one day.
Due to the hostile political environment at AAMC, senior management never takes responsibility for their inability to communicate effectively, or provide consistent direction to its staff.  
Senior management doesn’t communicate to other members of the senior management and doesn’t communicate with its staff. 
Unaccountable senior management often acted unprofessionally with no consequences for their inappropriate actions.
Center of Washington DC, so you had to deal with DC traffic and AAMC is 8 blocks from the nearest subway station.
Senior management doesn’t provide support to their staff in order for them to carry out the decisions senior staff makes.
When working for AAMC, walk very carefully, because you never know when you will step on a landmine or be held accountable for senior management’s stepping on the landmine.
If you take employment at AAMC, you probably wont enjoy the experience for the less than standard pay, unless you are senior management.

job_title: Senior Program Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Amazing Culture, professional development, flexible, amazing management , very supportive, encourages work/life balance, competitive salaries, promotion from within, diversity & inclusion, rooftop lounge
cons: Very focused on advance degrees for advancement but they pay tuition reimbursement.

job_title: Unix Systems Administrator in Washington, DC
pros: None Anymore; Maybe a Resume Builder?
cons: Toxic Work Environment, Gaslighting from Management, Terrible Contractors Replacing Employees

pros:
Flexible, generous vacation and sick days Generous 401k match.
Not too bad with Insurance.
Flexible work hours.
Occasional telecommuting.
Generous training opportunities , if in IT.
cons:
Not aggressive, beauracratic, tends to move slowly.
Tend to ignore junior employees.
Tend to be over managed.
Career stagnation possible.

review_title: Poor leadership, HR is too prescriptive with the results of DISC assessment
pros: They do have excellent benefits for a non-profit.
cons: Leadership is catty and there is lots of back biting. Ethically dubious use of internal resources against employees. Saw plenty on gender-based discrimination. Asked for help but HR could not be bothered.

review_title: Good place to work with great benefits
pros: The AAMC has fantastic benefits for employees including free health care. Additionally, the leadership seems to understand the importance of a good work/life balance to employee retention and productivity.
cons: I can't speak for how it is now. But as of 2014, there was not enough focus on trying to promote employees from within.

job_title: Program Specialist II in Laurel, MD
pros: Great benefits- Health, 401, and transportation.
cons: Senior Management play the buddy system. Your promotion depends on who you know. Limited room for growth.

review_title: AAMC a great place to work
pros: valuable mission with constituents who do important work; bright and motivated colleagues; good resources to accomplish work and reward employees
cons: there is a lot of work and sometimes the work-life balance doesn't really balance as much as you would like it to

pros: Intelligent colleagues, great atmosphere, good pay, GREAT benefits - FREE healthcare for employees.
cons: Location in DC, should open a satellite office for the commuters. Compensation for VRE and Metro  not enough for commuters from Vienna, VA or far in Maryland. Reorganization lowered morale. Separation between the "business" and IT departments.

pros: A lot of flex time, people are easy to work for, easy to work with. Management isnt the best, but a lot better than other places.
cons: You may make a little bit more elsewhere, but the benefits make it worth it if you are no driven by compensation.

pros: Great company mission, good friendly people, great benefits
cons: Sometimes bite off more than they can chew in IT.  Need more people who can actually do work, and less directors

job_title: IT Project Manager in Washington, DC
pros:
Short Work Hours
Low Stress Environment
Nice People
cons:
Lack of visibility in to organizational goals
Loose management
Unclear advancement opportunities
Over-reliance on subcontractors

pros: Great benefits package. I enjoyed the people I worked with.
cons: Very limited advancement opportunities. The culture is very geared towards research and academics - if these are not your areas of expertise, there is very little in the way of professional development.

pros: The benefits are amazing, except that you have to wait for certain time periods to use them.
cons: There  is no room for growth even when they say that it is. Lies.

pros:
1. Less work load.
2. Sufficient time to learn.
3. travel and health insurance benefits.
4. excellent trainings
cons: The way they give promotions is not good.

job_title: Senior Communications Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: People really care about the mission and are dedicated to trying to help constituents.
cons: Very inefficient and does not invest in technical architecture to really benefit constituents. Also a large percentage of revenue is generated off students.

review_title: Great experience and easy to work with
job_title: Client and Technical Support Analyst in Washington, DC
pros: Great benefits package, health care, 401k, and great management, flexible hours and vacation days
cons: Not a lot of opportunity to further your career, no opportunity for overtime or bonus pay

job_title: Accounts Receivable Supervisor in Washington, DC
pros: Great benefits and excellent staff.  They are a company that really cares about their staff members.
cons: Pay could be slightly higher given the industry.

pros: Salary and benefits are top notch. Thirty-five hour work week. Some terrific and talented staff and supervisors. Mission-centric focus.
cons: A very toxic work environment unless you are fortunate enough to be in one of the units/clusters that has talented and ethical leadership.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Washington, DC
pros: Great work life balance environment . Phenomenal professional development and  growth opportunities , including options for continuing education. AAMC invests in its people!
cons: The current health care benefits options  can be better.

pros: Great place to work if you want to be part of an impactful organization that is driven by a wide reaching mission.
cons: Some days can be a little heavy on the meetings

pros: Great organization, ceo is transparent.
cons: Dont expect to grow here. If you are looking to move into a director position, it wont happen.

pros: Great work life balance. Great people and environment. Mission Driven.
cons: Bureaucracy and red tape is quite prevalent and inhibits growth.

job_title: Human Resources Manager in Baltimore, MD
pros: Great executive leadership, community feel, ability to participate across the organization
cons: Opportunities to grow in leadership somewhat stagnant; only for a select few.

pros: Benefits are very good, professional staff, very aligned with core values.
cons: To much redtape, not strategic at all.  Not business oriented.

pros: I found management to be responsive and there were opportunities to advance.
cons: I worked here for four years and really enjoyed it.

review_title: Fantastic salary and benefits but the work can be slow. Not much room for advancement.
pros: Great benefits and work/life balance.
cons: Work can be very slow at times.

job_title: Senior Specialist, Student Diversity Affairs in Washington, DC
pros: Committed staff, salary, workplace environment, collegiality, learning opportunities, invested supervisors/managers.
cons: I did not experience "cons" while working for the AAMC.

pros: Great benefits, great internal movement potential, flexible work schedules for work-life balance
cons: Poor internal communication, very hierarchical, identity crises

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Washington, DC
pros: Great people, good work-life balance. Truly care about employees. great healthcare
cons: hard to get much engineering done.

pros: The organization does Interesting work
cons: From what I have seen advancement opportunities are hard to come by

pros: They are a family oriented employer. They understand when personal/family issues arise.
cons: Not enough employees too much work

pros: It had great benefits and people!
